moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4
comment: Before this tournament I'd have said this was a pretty good way to aim for a draw. But, the Adams-Anand game showed a new plan which should be studied closely.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3
comment: Kasparov follows in the footsteps of Adams. Pc3 defends Pd5 and clears the way for Qd1-a4.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5
comment: else White plays b2-b4 and makes it extremely difficult for Black to get any queen-side

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5
comment: The aim of this is to exploit the weak a4-e8 diagonal.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8
comment: As in a Caro-Kann variation Black accepts that Pg7 is weak and must be defended this awkward way. However, Qg4 is exposed and Pd4 & Ne5 are ill-supported, so Black has plenty of chances to survive. Perhaps one of the more important details is that White needs to retreat Ne5 to avoid another minor piece exchange. The more exchanges the easier it will be for Black to complete his development and the harder it would be for White to generate an attack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O
comment: Kasparov has a lot of courage. Here he offers a pawn, so he can spend the tempo developing pieces. He obviously thinks there's a way to fight for a win if his piece activity is sufficient.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7
comment: I'm not sure why he's allowing White to capture at f6 to double his f-file pawns, exposing Kf8 a little. Perhaps he thinks he'll be able to play ...Rh8-g8 to help his own piece development.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5
1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5

1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5
comment: Pawns don't generally fight pieces very well. The pawns move to block and the pieces just go around them.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4
comment: But sometimes, to break through a mass of pawns and when a piece sac. isn't going to be enough, another pawn must be used.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6
comment: Malcolm Pein: Ponomariov had been playing much quicker than Kasparov and his next couple of moves came quite fast to my surprise.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7
comment: One by one White attacks a weakness and Black defends. If White can find two weaknesses (or create them) Black will be hard-pressed to hang on.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4
comment: To this point Black has made nine pawn moves compared to White's four. Certainly the extra four moves could have been used by Black to keep his king safer and his pieces more active; but at the beginning it seemed so much easier. It's like watching a small snowball rolling down a hill, growing larger and faster as it goes.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4 29. axb5 axb5 30. Bxb5 Qe5
comment: Is there's still no way for Rh8 to move into play? Apparently Pc5 is too weak to spend any "free" tempos on general piece activation.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4 29. axb5 axb5 30. Bxb5 Qe5 31. Qg5 Qe7 32. Qh6 Be6 33. Qf4
comment: Malcolm Pein: John H tells me GK made the control with a couple of minutes to spare. Looks like he missed the kill first time round. MH: This almost looks like an admission his attack has run out of steam. If he can't move Rd6 with an effective discovery on Rc7 and if he can't break through the light squares around Kf7 then Black might be only a little worse (his king is still less secure than Kg1) .

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4 29. axb5 axb5 30. Bxb5 Qe5 31. Qg5 Qe7 32. Qh6 Be6 33. Qf4 Bc8
comment: He avoids the most obvious discovery, Rd6xe6.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4 29. axb5 axb5 30. Bxb5 Qe5 31. Qg5 Qe7 32. Qh6 Be6 33. Qf4 Bc8 34. Qh6

1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Nxf6+ Nxf6 7. c3 c5 8. Ne5 Nd7 9. Bb5 Bd6 10. Qg4 Kf8 11. O-O Nxe5 12. dxe5 Bxe5 13. Bg5 Bf6 14. Rad1 Qc7 15. Qh4 Bxg5 16. Qxg5 f6 17. Qh5 g6 18. Qh6+ Kf7 19. Rd3 a6 20. Rh3 Qe7 21. Bd3 f5 22. g4 Qf6 23. Rd1 b5 24. Be2 e5 25. Rhd3 Ra7 26. Rd6 Qg7 27. Qe3 Rc7 28. a4 e4 29. axb5 axb5 30. Bxb5 Qe5 31. Qg5 Qe7 32. Qh6 Be6 33. Qf4 Bc8 34. Qh6 Be6 35. gxf5 gxf5 36. Be2 Qf6 37. Bh5+ Ke7 38. Rxe6+
comment: The capture works after all. 38...Qxe6 allows 39. Qg7+ to win Rh8 and 38...Ke6 allows 39. Rd6+ which wins Qf6. This relentless attack wasn't so flashy as many, but it was very accurate and showed the pawns can't leave a king exposed without major consequences. In this case the defense was good, but the position was (apparently) irreparable. That the White pieces won this and the Adams-Anand games using this same (new to my knowledge) opening idea is notable. Anand didn't lose because of it, he misplayed a queen and pawn ending, but Ponomariov never quite recovered from the positional weaknesses around his king, created during the opening and early middle-game. Kasparov takes the lead in the tournament with only one round to go!
